headline: Butternut Squash Risotto
description: A butternut squash risotto recipe for those who love the sweet flavor of butternut squash. An easy risotto with a creamy taste, full of flavor.

video.description: Make a creamy risotto with naturally sweet butternut squash.
video.name: Butternut Squash Risotto

name: Butternut Squash Risotto
recipeIngredient: salt and ground black pepper to taste

recipeInstructions.text: Place squash into a steamer basket in a saucepan; fill with water to just below the bottom of the basket. Cover, bring to a boil, and steam squash until tender, 10 to 15 minutes. Drain; use a fork to mash squash in a bowl.

Melt butter in a saucepan over medium-high heat. Add onion; cook and stir for 2 minutes until onion begins to soften, then stir in rice. Continue cooking and stirring until rice is glossy and the onion begins to brown on the edges, about 5 minutes more.

Pour in white wine; cook, stirring constantly, until it has evaporated. Stir in mashed squash and 1/3 of the hot chicken stock; reduce heat to medium. Cook and stir until chicken stock has been absorbed into rice, 5 to 7 minutes. Add 1/2 of the remaining chicken stock, and continue stirring until it has been absorbed. Finally, pour in remaining stock, and continue stirring until the risotto is creamy.
Stir in Parmesan cheese and season with salt and pepper.

review.reviewBody: Steamed small butternut squash cubes in microwave for 3 minutes to soften. Then sauteed squash in olive oil with minced garlic, salt, pepper and paprika. Did not mash squash. Reduced chicken stock to 3 1/2 cups and followed the recipe for the rest of the preparation. The result was a very flavorful side dish because of garlic and paprika. Paired well with a walnut-crusted baked tilapia.

Turned out great. I halved and seeded my squash and then roasted at 400 for about 45 minutes. Then scooped out leaving the flesh and put into he risotto. My hubby really liked it. Served with Steak and asparagus.

Delicious base recipe. Added 2 oz pancetta and substituted shallots for onions. Waited to add squash until risotto was cooked, because I like to taste the squash. Garlic would probably be a good addition too.
Very nice but needs an herbal component. Take your choice!

This was easy to make and the technique was simple. I used a ricer for the squash. The flavor is not for me. It needed more savoriness. I added double the amount of Parmesan to offset and lots of pepper but it was not for me. Thanks for a change.
I LOVE this recipe. I adopted a few of the suggestions in the reviews, roasted the butternut squash for 45 minutes and only used 3 cups of chicken stock. It was amazing!
MISE EN PLACE, because this comes together fast and requires constant attention!! Absolutely perfect. My husband asked me to marry him again after he tasted it
My husband and very picky eater mother loved it. I used about 4 c stock. Next time will stop at 3 cups. Otherwise, followed recipe as is.
This recipe was easy to make and delicious. I doubled the ingredients and used Acorn Squash instead of Butternut. Off the charts!

I going to make this as soon as I finish typing this, but I want to offer a shortcut for those wrestling with peeling the squash: a regular vegetable peeler works! I discovered this out of desperation. I didn't want to bake the squash to get the flesh out; it takes too long, and I'm terrible with a paring knife. Peel the bulbous end first; it gives you something to hang on to. They can get quite slippery.
I roasted the squash instead of steaming.
Delicious.

I did not measure the butternut squash and just put the entire squash in the recipe because I didn’t want to waste it.and couldn’t think of s other use. Next time Ill stick to the 2 cups and freeze the rest because it overpowered the risotto
I used all the bouillon, but cut back around 1 cup of water. This is excellent! I peeled and steamed the squash in the microwave before preparing the rest of the dish. I am glad that I did this.
Perfect
I roasted the butternut squash and mashed it up before adding it to the risotto. I followed the rest of the recipe as is. It was absolutely delicious!

I didn’t use Arboro rice, just the long grain I had. I only used 4 cups of canned chicken broth. And I add some minced garlic with the onion step. Phenomenal! Some chefs might say that if you love someone, make them risotto!
I roasted my squash with garlic and olive oil rather than steaming. Added Parmesan and gruyere cheese for another kick of flavor, it was fantastic!!
Great recipe!!! Delicious, healthy, beautiful and easy to make!

This is an excellent use of butternut squash. The only thing it needs is seasoning. I kept it simple with salt and pepper and a little Mrs. Dash. I also cut the entire recipe in half as there are just two in our family. It divided nicely. I will definitely make this again.
I had the hardest time with this recipe. my rice never cooked after an hour and I added alot more water. I used sweet potatoes instead of squash.

My family loved it, I wasn’t a huge fan. The onion was a little too strong for me.
Probably won’t make it again.

Awesome the first few times I made this. Today I made 2 changes. Added 1/2 teaspoon saffron threads & 1 1/2 ounces diced pancetta. Still awesome!! Side to smoked Turkey Legs placed into a slow cooker for 7 hours.

No one objected to this meal, but no one was wild about it. We found it lacking the umami and pizazz to be a main dish, but thought it would make an excellent side. The flavors are not strong or distinct, so as a side, it would not compete with or overshadow a main. We added extra parm and a hefty amount of black pepper to make it more to our liking.

This is my first time cooking risotto. I had exactly 2 cups of leftover butternut squash from last night’s dinner, and quite by mistake my husband purchased risotto when I sent him for medium grain rice for another recipe. So here I was, with leftover squash and a bag of risotto that I didn’t know how to prepare. It looks marvelous even as it’s cooking and having tasted it a couple of times, I think everyone will love it. I definitely will make it again.
Excellent! I may have used more than two cups of squash, but my wife raved about it, so it’s a keeper!
This was amazing!!! Will be making it again

I made this vegan. Used veggie stock and added garlic with the onions. Topped it off with a little vegan cheese, but found out this was unnecessary due to the creaminess of the squash already. It was a great recipe to start off with, thanks!!
Great way to use up my butternut squash! I added 1 tsp of allspice but did everything else as written. I'll make it again.
This recipe is outstanding! LOVED IT!
Creamy and delicious. It’s a bit different making the risotto with the squash added at the beginning. But the taste is really good!
This recipe is delicious. I made it as written with a squash from my garden and we enjoyed it very much.
This was an easy to follow and great tasting side dish. Reminded me of something you would get in an upscale restaurant right in my own home.

Delicious. Will make again. Next time will roast the squash in the oven instead of steaming it stovetop. 
Takes longer for the risotto to cook than advertised.
Worth the effort.
Made this at thanksgiving for a different side, but with all of the other sides competing... this was not a big hit. It was ok.
My family and I love this one! Great fall dish!

This is wonderfully delicious! Followed the recipe closely save 1 exception - we only added 2 cups chicken stock and felt it was sufficient. Pulled the squash from our garden which made it even better! Will make again.
Great recipe, I used Hubbard squash. My entire family liked it.
Delicious. Left out the wine for the little ones but they loved it and thought this was mac and cheese

It is good. I love butternut squash. Good mix with Arborio. I thought mushrooms would be good in it too. Cooking time is long on the stove. So probably won't make it again until cool weather. I had a little Parm cheese and I put grated Romano on top. I put it in a corningware dish.
one of my go tos
Very simple and do-able recipe that isn't too heavy, and makes a great side to a roasted chicken, it's a crowd pleaser and did I mention SO SIMPLE
My niece who doesn't like vegetables really liked it. My sister said she could eat this every day!!!

I have made this several times now. So delicious! But we prefer not to purée the squash, instead to oven roast it in small cubes with a bit of olive oil for ~1/2 hour while the risotto is cooking. Then add the butternut squash just before serving.
Absolutely delicious! I ended up baking my butternut squash at 375 F for 45 minutes, flipping halfway. The taste from the baked squash was amazing, even if it didn't mash as well.

The peeler for the squash is not the typical one but the one that has the blade going crosswise. This makes peeling the squash easy. This is my first risotto and I am not a big fan of the texture, but it is fine as far as taste goes
I used this recipe as a basis for a dinner. I used brown rice ILO risotto, added mushrooms and allspice per others’ suggestions, used cream of chicken ILO chicken stock, and added spinach. Yum!!!!!!
Easy to make and delicious!

I love this recipe with the addition of a balsamic glaze drizzled over the top and toasted and salted pumpkin seeds sprinkled on top as well. Sometimes I serve it with brown butter cooked scallops on top as well. Depends on my mood.
Haven't tried this yet, but want to as I eat butternut squash a lot. AM currently trying to do a low carb diet, and need to modify this with cauliflower rice.
Outstanding!
The risotto came out excellent, super creamy. But 1 cup of onion is way to much onion flavor in this. I couldnt taste the squash at all.
I peeled, cubed, & roasted the squash instead of steaming it and it was fantastic - I think roasting brings out the best of butternut’s flavors. I will make this again (& again).
Turned out great and everyone really enjoyed it! I followed the recipe as written.

I used others suggestions and cut down on the amount of broth - using 3 cups in total (added 1 cup at a time). It turned out perfect! I also roasted the squash in a little olive oil with salt and pepper rather than steaming. As an extra luxury, I used shaved parmesan.
Anything the whole family likes, deserves 5 stars. I will make this again and toss in some herbs, either thyme or sage to see if that makes it more interesting for the adult palates.

SO good. I followed other reviewers' advice and doubled the rice and squash. I also added a pinch of cinnamon and some Anna's Homemade Garlic Salt (from Etsy). To make it more of a meal I poached 2 chicken breasts and shredded them. I added them at the very end. I also added more parmesan because, well, why wouldn't you? This was a big hit even with my 4 year old, and my 7 month old!
This was so delicious, I added 2 large chopped and sautéed portobellos and it added great texture and flavor.
For the first time making risotto, it come out great.... family loved it! Wouldn’t change a thing....
So deliscous. Perfect for leftover squash!

My husband is not a fan of butternut squash but he really liked this. I added fresh sage at the end which helped offset some of the sweetness. Paired it with roasted chicken thighs for a wonderful dinner.

i will make it again and I made it to the recipe although I halved it. Delicious and the butternut squash was easy to mash and it cooked right down easily. The only thing I didn't do was to heat the broth. Didn't seem to affect the cooking time, although it was already warm in my kitchen since it's early autumn.

I followed this recipe exactly as written and it is awesome! I’ve made this countless times and it is always a hit. You definitely have to have patience though and ensure the rice soaks up all the liquid. It is time consuming but worth it.
I’ve made this recipe multiple times, and love it! I? shred my squash (use about a cup shredded) to make it easier on myself.

This was quite good. I didn't use nearly as much of the chicken stock, but it still turned out quite good. I also omitted the Parmesan cheese, because I didn't have any. Instead I added a sheep's milk cheese, finely diced. Dark Horse Chardonnay goes quite well in it and with it.
This is one of my favorite recipes. Delicious for dinner and also a special treat reheated. All that and it's an entire meal in itself!

Great recipe. Only changes I made was I roasted the squash instead of messing around with peeling and chopping it up. I used a shallot instead of an onion because that's all I had laying around. Definitely make sure you salt and pepper at the end. I served this with a balsamic marinated chicken breast and it was delicious!
I don't generally like risotto but I had butternut squash's to use so I tried it. It was really easy and I thoroughly enjoyed it. I guess I like risotto now.

Very good
I used pre cut and peeled squash
Soooo much easier

Loved this recipe. Like many others, I roasted the squash for about an hour, and then pureed it with a pinch of cinnamon and a cup of broth. I added garlic and diced mushrooms, cooking them with the onions in the butter. I also used 1/3 of a cup of parmesan cheese, and only used 3 cups of broth (inclusive of the cup used for the puree). I mixed in the puree closer to the end, and seasoned only with a bit of pepper after the cheese was fully blended in. It worked out perfectly. Tasted delicious. Will definitely make this again.

I followed the recipe using the adjustments from recommendations to use less broth (3 cups) and wait to add the butternut squash at the end. It did enhance the taste. I also added a bit more parmesan and a dash of brown sugar, and used shallots and garlic instead of onions (as I was out of onions). All worked nicely. At the very end, last thing - I added some cinnamon, but I likely wouldn't do that next time as it changed the taste to much, and I liked the taste before I added the cinnamon. Thanks for the recipe.
Fabulous! The only change is I roasted squash & added garlic salt. Fabulous. I don't think the Parmesan cheese was needed & you could saute onions in olive oil vs. butter to cut calories/fat.
one of my family and friends' favorites!!
Loved it. Delicious was a hit with company. Served it with maple mustard glazed pork loin roast and hericot verts.

Added less broth than called for and it was still runny before I cooked and let evaporate an extra 20 minutes or so. Squash flavor is easily overpowered by the Parmesan so be careful not to use too much, I didn’t measure as I added and regretted it.

Delish!! I make it as the recipe states except that I throw all the roasted squash in right before I start adding the broth most of the squash melts down to give the whole dish a creamy, hearty flavor. Some of the pieces stay whole as well and adds to the perfect consistency. The best compliment I can give is that not only does it satisfy my foodie side of the family, but my picky toddler and no-frills hubby always clear their plates! (We call it fancy mac and cheese around here)

Delicious! I recommend roasting the squash in the oven for 40 minutes or so to bring out the sweetness. I added chopped red mustard greens to mine, which came out fantastically. I imagine any leafy green, such as kale or turnip greens, would go well in it, too!
Delicious! I will make this again it was that good. The butternut squash was so good in the risotto.
Delicious! One of my favorite risottos to make! Great for fall!

We loved it! Instead of steaming the squash, I roasted it before mashing because we love the flavor that develops in roasting. I used all 5 cups of stock, unlike some of the other reviewers. It takes longer for the rice to absorb the extra liquid, but the dish is worth the time. Yummy!
Terrible - very bland. It takes about 4 times as long as this recipe indicates to cook the rice. I don’t know how this recipe has above two stars.

The dish is excellent and I recommend it alongside Mary's Meatloaf (an Allrecipes fav of mine), sauteed fresh spinach, homemade french bread, and a green salad - a beautiful Sunday afternoon meal that fed the body and the soul. I chose to roast my butternut squash in the oven (instead of steaming it as the recipe directs). I cut the squash in half (length-wise), brushed the flesh with olive oil, salt and pepper, some high quality lightly dried sage, and roasted it (flesh up) until it was completely cooked. I scooped the squash out with a fork and added it to the risotto as it was cooking. It's dishes like this risotto that make fall such a delicious, magical time of year.
My son helped me make this (he did most of the stirring) my family absolutely love this dish. Easy to make and a great way to use some of the butternut squash from the garden!
Good but not as good as the traditional parmesan and pea risotto.
I won't make this recipe again.....followed directions to the tee....kind of bland

I did not have the dry wine so I used Moscato. I did not have arborio rice so I used yellow rice. I added chopped mushrooms with the onions. Other than that I followed the recipe. My husband said he could eat it over and over. It was very easy and simple to make.
Eyla
This was easy and very flavorful. Nothing to change on this one!! It takes a little time for the additions of the broth but so worth it. It is just plain classy

Freaking delicious! Made as per recipe except veggi broth instead of chicken broth.. I was skeptacle about the amount of liquid, but followed the recipe and it was spot on fantastic!!! Will make this a monthly staple in my kitchen; thanks!!!

For the squash, I cut in quarters, removed seeds, microwaved for 8 mins, scooped out the cooked squash, mashed with a fork! Easy, no mess, and no peeling necsssary!

WOW! This recipe is an absolute winner. I tried this last night, it was my first time making any sort of risotto and it came out better than restaurant quality. After reading other's complaints there was two much chicken stock, I halved the portion. It came out splendid, this is definitely going to be a staple in our home.

This was so good! I have a very picky nephew who even ate it. I used 1.5 cups of rice, and added water to the broth for a total of about 5 cups, but I didn't measure, so I'm not sure how much it actually was. I also roasted the squash instead of steaming, as others had suggested. My kids don't really like onions, so I omitted those. I will be making this again. I served it with a rotisserie chicken.
I agree with jaimebuggy. Bake your squash to make everything easier. I doubled the recipe and found that 3/4 of the liquid worked well.
This came out delicious!!
Made this and the risotto turned out very well! I would beware not to add too much Parmesan as it can easily over power the other flavours. Would definitely make again!
Ever since I made this I've been craving it again! It's so divine and creamy and delicious!
Love this recipe. Always a hit with my family. I usually do a 1.5 multiple so I have leftovers for work. The only change I make is slightly more squash.
This was awesome. Read reviews and baked the squash first then scooped it into a bowl. Also waited to add the squash till the last batch of stock was added. It's a keeper:)

Followed the advice of many reviewers, only used 3 cups of broth and added the squash at the end after the majority of the broth was absorbed. I also added a 1/2 tsp of sage as also recommended, it was just a touch bland without, will add a little more next time. A hit with our NYE dinner and I will make it again when I need a good arm workout!!

This is a delicious side dish. As other reviews stated, 3 cups of the chicken stock was plenty. I added some garlic to it as well. Will try adding cinnamon next time. I'll definitely be making this again!

This recipe is a good base, but with a few tweaks it can be changed from bland to delicious! Like others have said I cut and placed the butternut squash in the oven for an hour at 400 which made it so much easier to mash. However, next time I will probably get a can or try some other method in order to make this quicker. Added in some cinnamon, nutmeg, and garlic (with the onions) in order to give it some flavor and it tasted amazing! I actually did use quite a bit of chicken stock (~4 cups) in order to make the arborio rice become soft and make the dish creamier so I would suggest placing the stock cup by cup and add more if you feel like it is needed. Also, I added the butternut squash after the first several cups of stock in order to make sure the rice absorbed the liquid properly. Perfect dish for fall and if these extra ingredients are added, the dish becomes both sweet and savory.
